facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1951 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 15 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Decree dated 29th August 1944 of High Court of Allahabad by Mulla and Yorke JJ. in First Appeal No. 157 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree, dated the 29th August. 1944, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Mulla and Yorke JJ.

facts.text: High Court appeal arose from Judgment and Decree dated 19th November 1941 of Civil Judge at Banaras in Original Suit No. 79 of 1941.

anchor.surface_text: in First Appeal No. 157 of 1942, arising out of the Judgment and Decree, dated the 19th November, 1941, of the Court of the Civil Judge at Banaras in Original Suit No. 79 of 1941.

facts.text: Plaintiff commenced Original Suit No. 79 of 1941 in Court of Civil Judge at Banaras for pre-emption of plot D 37/48 in Mohalla Baradeo, Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, who is the appellant before us, companymenced the suit, out of which this appeal arises, in the Court of the Civil Judge at Banaras  being Original Suit No. 79 of 1941  for enforcement of his right of pre-emption in respect of an enclosed plot of land with certain structures upon it, situated within Moballa Baradeo in the city of Banaras and bearing Municipal No. D 37/48.

facts.text: Premises belonged to defendants Nos. 2 to 5, residents of Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The premises in suit admitted by belonged to defendants Nos. 2 to 5, who are residents of Calcutta

facts.text: Defendants 2-5 sold the property by conveyance executed on 29th March 1941, registered on 3rd April 1941 to defendant No. 1, resident of Calcutta, for Rs. 7,000.

anchor.surface_text: and they sold. it by a companyveyance executed on the 29th March, 1941, and registered on the 3rd of April following, to defendant No. 1, also a resident of Calcutta, for the price of Rs. 7,000.

facts.text: Plaintiff owns premises D 37/85 and D 37/44 in same Mohalla, adjoining the suit property on northern and eastern sides.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff is the owner of the two premises to wit, premises Nos. D 37/85 and D 37 /44, within the same Mohalla of the city of Banaras, which are in close proximity to the property in dispute and adjoin it on the numberthern and eastern sides respectively.

facts.text: Plaintiff claims custom of pre-emption in Banaras on ground of vicinage from very early time.

anchor.surface_text: It is averred by the plaintiff that there is from very early, time a custom prevalent in the city of Banaras according to which the plaintiff was entitled to claim pre- emption of the property in dispute on the ground of vicinage.

facts.text: Plaintiff made immediate assertion of pre-emption rights as per Muhammadan Law and sent registered notice to defendant No.1 on 21st May 1941.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that as soon as the plaintiff received news of the sale, he made an immediate assertion or demand of his rights and repeated the same in the presence of the witnesses as required by Muhammadan Law and he further sent a registered numberice to defendant No. I on the 21st May, 1941,

facts.text: Defendant No.1 denied existence of custom of pre-emption amongst Muslims in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant No. 1 alone companytested the suit and the pleas taken by him in his written statement can be classified under four heads. In the first place, he denied that there was any custom of pre-emption amongst numberMuslims in the city of Banaras as alleged by the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 claimed custom not available since vendors and vendee residents of different province, not natives/domiciled in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The second plea taken was that even if there was any custom of pre-emption it companyld number be availed of in a case like this where neither the vendors number the vendee were natives of or domiciled in Banaras but were residents of a different province.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 claimed plaintiff did not make proper demands as per Muhammadan Law.

anchor.surface_text: The third companytention raised was that the plaintiff had number made the two demands in the proper manner as required by Muhammadan Law and by reason of number-compliance with the essential pre-requisites to a claim for preemption, the suit -was bound to fail.

facts.text: Defendant No.1 claimed plaintiff as landlord cannot pre-empt against own tenants.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was companytended that as the plaintiff himself was the landlord of the property in suit and the, vendors were his tenants, he companyld number, under any law or custom, eject his own tenants by exercise of the right of pre-emption.

facts.text: Civil Judge held custom of pre-emption exists in Banaras same as Muhammadan Law.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge who tried the suit held, on the evidence adduced in the case, that there was in fact a custom of pre- emption in the city of Banaras, the incidents of which were the same as in Muhammadan Law.

facts.text: Civil Judge held custom local, not enforceable against non-natives/domiciled vendors or vendee.

anchor.surface_text: He held however that the custom being a local custom it companyld number be enforced against either the vendors or the vendee in the present case, as numbere of them were natives of or domiciled in Banaras.

facts.text: Civil Judge found plaintiff did not make requisite demands under Muhammadan Law.

anchor.surface_text: The trial judge also found that the plaintiff did number make the requisite demands which are -mandatory under Muhammadan Law.

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed suit, did not decide landlord-tenant pre-emption issue.

anchor.surface_text: The result was that the plaintiffs suit was dismissed and in view of the findings arrived at by him, the Civil Judge did number companysider it necessary to decide the question as to whether the plaintiff being himself a landlord companyld assert any claim for pre-emption against his tenants on the basis of a custom.

facts.text: High Court agreed custom exists but requires vendor and vendee natives/domiciled in Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges agreed with the trial Court in holding that although there was a custom of pre-emption in the city of Banaras, -yet the necessary companydition for enforcing the custom in that locality was that the vendor and the vendee must be natives of or domiciled in the city.

facts.text: High Court affirmed dismissal of suit on 29th August 1944.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the High Court affirmed the decision of the trial judge and dismissed the appeal. The judgment of the High Court is dated the 29th August, 1944.

facts.text: High Court left undecided demands compliance and landlord pre-emption issues.

anchor.surface_text: The other questions as to whether the plaintiff had made thedemands in strict companypliance with the rules of Muhammadan Law and whether he companyld claim pre-emption against his own tenants on the basis of a right by custom were left undecided.

facts.text: Plaintiff got special leave from Judicial Committee on 11th December 1945.

anchor.surface_text: After this, the plaintiff applied for leave to appeal to the Judicial Committee. This application was refused by the High Court but he got special leave under an order of the Judicial Committee, dated the 11th December, 1945.

facts.text: Appeal transferred to Supreme Court after abolition of Judicial Committee jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: After the abolition of the jurisdiction of the Judicial Committee the appeal stood transferred to this Court for disposal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds custom of pre-emption exists in entire city of Banaras without restriction to natives or domiciled persons.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that a local custom of preemption exists in the city of Banaras and the right attaches at least to all house properties situated within it and numberincident of such custom is proved which would make the right available only between persons who are either natives of Banaras or -are domiciled therein.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal, sets aside lower courts judgments, remands to High Court for undecided issues.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal is allowed and the judgments of both the Courts below are set aside. The case shall go back to the High Court for companysideration of the two questions left undecided by it, namely, whether the plaintiff has made the demands in due companypliance with the forms prescribed by the Muhammadan Law and secondly whether the plaintiff, being a landlord,

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has been mooted before us is, whether the burden and benefit of a right of pre-emption are incidents annexed to the lands belonging respectively to the vendor and the Pre-emptor or is the right merely one of re- purchase, which a neighbour or co-sharer enjoys under Muhammadan Law, and which he can enforce personally against the vendee in whom the title to the property has already vested by sale.

anchor.surface_text: The question now arises as to what is the legal position when the right is claimed not under Muhammadan Law but on the footing of a custom. It cannot be and is not disputed that if the right of pre-emption is set, up by non-Muslims on the basis of a custom, the existence of the custom is a matter to be established by proper evidence.

holdings.text: A local custom of pre-emption exists in the city of Banaras and the right attaches at least to all house properties situated within it and no incident of such custom is proved which would make the right available only between persons who are either natives of Banaras or are domiciled therein.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that a local custom of preemption exists in the city of Banaras and the right attaches at least to all house properties situated within it and numberincident of such custom is proved which would make the right available only between persons who are either natives of Banaras or -are domiciled therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Custom judicially recognised in Banaras; defendants failed to prove restrictive incident to natives/domiciled; presumption of co-extensiveness with Muhammadan Law; lex loci nature binds all property owners.

holdings.text: Custom of pre-emption in Banaras admits no restriction to natives or domiciled persons; binds all owners of property in the city irrespective of residence or origin.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that a local custom of preemption exists in the city of Banaras and the right attaches at least to all house properties situated within it and numberincident of such custom is proved which would make the right available only between persons who are either natives of Banaras or -are domiciled therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected lower courts and textbooks (Wilson, Mulla, Tyabji) relying on flawed precedents like Byjnath; custom is lex loci affecting all lands irrespective of owners' religion/nationality/domicile; no evidence of restriction.

holdings.text: The right of pre-emption under Muhammadan Law is not a mere personal right of re-purchase but an incident annexed to the land imposing a limitation/disability on the owner's right of sale; benefit and burden run with the land.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prefer Allahabad FB (Mahmood J.) over Calcutta FB (mistranslation of 'Tajibo'); right antecedent to sale, condition precedent to enforceability; avoids stranger introduction; real right like servitude.

holdings.text: When right of pre-emption rests upon custom, it becomes the lex loci or law of the place and affects all lands situated therein irrespective of religion, nationality or domicile of owners (unless proved part of custom).

anchor.surface_text: The companyrect legal position must be that when a right of pre- emption rests upon custom it becomes the lex loci or the law of the place and affects all lands situated in that place irrespective of the religion or nationality or domicile of the owners of the lands except where such incidents are proved to be a part of the custom itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes personal law application to Muhammadans (equity basis) from territorial custom; analogies to codified statutes; rejects personal right assumption underlying prior cases.

holdings.text: Custom of pre-emption amongst non-Muslims presumed founded on and co-extensive with Muhammadan Law unless contrary shown; preliminary demands required.

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council in Jadhulal v. Janki Koer expressly laid down that when a custom of pre-emption is established by evidence to prevail amongst number-Muslims in a particular locality it must be presumed to be founded on and company extensive with the Muhammadan Law on that subject unless the companytrary is shown that the Court may as between Hindus ad- minister a modification of the law as to the circumstances under which the right may be claimed when it is shown that the custom in that respect does number go to the whole length of the Muhammadan Law of preemption, but that the assertion of right by suit must always be preceded by an observance of the preliminary forms prescribed in the Muhammadan Law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly follows Privy Council (Jadulal v Janki Koer); applied to Banaras custom; no contrary evidence adduced.

holdings.text: Custom of pre-emption in Banaras takes judicial notice; existence generally known and recognised, no further proof necessary.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Judicial Committee and prior Allahabad decisions; multiple judgments affirm existence in Banaras.
